misconceptions.name: Program reads point coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1 for 'Reading numeric grade input'. The program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 and reads four doubles instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to read coordinates for two points rather than a single numeric grade value.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should prompt for a single numeric grade (0-100), e.g., 'Enter grade: ', and read exactly one numeric value representing that grade.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'x1 and y1' and 'x2 and y2' instead of 'Enter grade'
Multiple doubles (x1, y1, x2, y2) are read instead of one grade variable
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismatch between the assignment specification and the implemented problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input section to prompt for a single grade value (e.g., an int or double) and store it in a variable named grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompts and variable names clearly indicate the student is solving a distance problem rather than reading a numeric grade.

evidence.note: Reads four coordinate values x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single numeric grade input.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic for A and B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1 for 'Correct Boolean ranges for A and B'. The program contains no if/else logic checking whether the numeric grade is in the 90–100 (A) or 80–89 (B) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to compute a distance using a mathematical formula without any need for conditional grade ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use conditional statements (if/else-if) to test whether the grade is between 90 and 100 for 'A' and between 80 and 89 for 'B'.
symptoms: No if or else-if statements in the program
No variables or expressions involving grade ranges or comparisons to 80 or 90
misconceptions.root_cause: The algorithm implemented is entirely for distance calculation and ignores grade range logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: After reading the grade, add an if/else-if chain that checks grade >= 90 for 'A' and grade >= 80 for 'B', with correct upper bounds.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: There are no conditional statements at all, so correct A/B range handling is impossible.

evidence.note: Computes a distance and prints it; there is no conditional logic for grading ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: No conditional logic for C and D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1 for 'Correct Boolean ranges for C and D'. The program never checks whether a grade is in the 70–79 (C) or 60–69 (D) ranges.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that only the distance calculation is required, so they did not include any mid-range grade checks.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should include Boolean conditions to detect when the numeric grade is between 70 and 79 for 'C' and between 60 and 69 for 'D'.
symptoms: Absence of any conditions involving 60 or 70
No letters C or D appear in the output
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to implement the grading specification at all, including middle grade ranges.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else-if chain to include range checks for 70–79 (print 'C') and 60–69 (print 'D').
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditions based on grade values, so C/D ranges cannot be present.

evidence.note: Entire program lacks any conditional checks for C or D ranges.

misconceptions.name: No default/else case for failing grade (F)
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1 for 'Correct handling of F (default/else)'. There is no conditional logic, so the program cannot assign 'F' to grades below 60 or handle it as a default case.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that only producing a numeric distance is necessary, not covering all grade cases including failing grades.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After handling A–D with explicit conditions, the program should use an else branch (or equivalent) to classify any remaining grades as 'F'.
symptoms: No else or default branch present
No 'F' letter appears in any output string
misconceptions.root_cause: Because the grading logic is entirely missing, there is no structure in which an 'F' default case could exist.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Once you've added conditions for A–D, add a final else that outputs 'F' for any grade below 60.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: With no conditionals and no output of 'F', correct handling of failing grades is clearly absent.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Only prints a distance; there is no alternate branch or default behavior for grades below 60.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs numeric distance instead of letter grade
misconceptions.description: Score: 0/1 for 'Mapping each range to correct letter output'. The program prints 'The distance of the two points is ...' with a numeric value, rather than 'Letter grade: A/B/C/D/F' based on the input grade.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the required output is a numeric distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For any input grade, the program should output a letter grade message such as 'Letter grade: B', matching the specified ranges.
symptoms: Output string mentions 'distance of the two points' instead of 'Letter grade'
No single-character letter grades are printed
misconceptions.root_cause: The student implemented a completely different problem, so the output format does not match the grading specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance message with logic that prints 'Letter grade: ' followed by A, B, C, D, or F depending on the grade.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric categories to symbolic labels
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only output line clearly refers to distance and not to letter grades.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Final output prints a numeric distance rather than any letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem (distance calculator) instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: Total score: 0/5. The submission implements a distance-between-two-points calculator rather than the required grade-to-letter converter. As a result, none of the rubric criteria (input of a single grade, range checks for A–D, default F handling, and correct letter output) are satisfied.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the assignment is to compute the Euclidean distance between two points given their coordinates.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment is to read a single numeric grade (0–100) and output the corresponding letter grade (A–F) according to the specified ranges.

Output describes distance instead of letter grades
No grading logic or grade variable is present
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different questions or reuse of code from another problem without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement for Q3 and write a new program from scratch that focuses on reading one grade, using if/else-if to test the given ranges, and printing the matching letter grade.
related_concepts: Designing programs around required input and output behavior
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every aspect of the code (name, variables, logic, output) aligns with a distance problem, not a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Overall structure and naming indicate a distance calculator, not a grade calculator.

evidence.note: The entire program calculates distance instead of grading, rendering all rubric items unmet.

misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong problem (distance calculator instead of grade calculator)
